Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Tasmanian Tidal Dissipation Experiment (T-TIDE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit

Tidal mixing of the deep ocean does not necessarily occur where energy is lost from the barotropic tide, but rather where the low-mode baroclinic tide dissipates, perhaps thousands of kilometers away. Ocean general circulation models are sensitive to the magnitude and geography of deep mixing, but very few observations of this process exist. Understanding the location and mechanisms of tidal dissipation is necessary for their continued improvement. The Tasmanian Tidal Dissipation Experiment?s (T-TIDE) hypothesis is that significant tidal dissipation takes place where propagating low-mode internal tides impinge on steep continental slopes. Slope geometry affects wave reflection, transmission, scattering, and breaking, which in turn determine the spatial distribution of mixing. Important breaking mechanisms may include lee effects at small-scale bathymetry and nonlinear bore formation near critical slopes. We propose a coordinated observational/modeling effort to understand the physics geometry, and magnitude of dissipation and mixing. The goals are to 1) identify where mixing occurs on the continental slope, 2) determine the dominant dissipative processes, 3) assess the amount of energy transmitted onto the shelf and reflected back into the deep sea to be dissipated elsewhere, and 4) generalize these results as a parameterization of topographic scattering and dissipation in numerical models, which ideally depends on the topography, stratification, and the barotropic and/or low-mode baroclinic tides. The three main components to the experimental plan are 1) intensive 2D and 3D modeling before and after the fieldwork to plan and contextualize the measurements; 2) a glider based Scout Experiment to identify dynamic processes, evaluate models, and finalize mooring sites; and 3) a comprehensive Process Experiment using ships, gliders, and moorings with the time and space resolution to address T-TIDEs hypothesis and achieve its goals. An array of profiling and fixed-sensor moorings will be combined with gliders acting as virtual moorings. Tidally-resolving or higher-frequency observations will measure internal wave motions, energy fluxes, and dissipation and mixing either directly or via finescale parameterizations. An altimetric analysis of internal-tide sea surface height will assess mesoscale refraction of the incident internal tide along with Australian gliders, which will monitor hydrography and internal tidal displacements in the Tasman Sea.

Broader Impacts

The proposed work will provide global insights on the dissipation of tidal energy. Specifically, inclusion of tidal dissipation on continental slopes may be an important component of the next generation of mixing parameterizations in climate models. Graduate students will be trained as part of the experiment. In addition to its scientific import, T-TIDE will sponsor and participate in two training seminars with high school science teachers who are charged with delivering the earth science program in San Diego Unified School District. This effort will be performed in conjunction with the Birch Aquarium at Scripps. Finally, an essential element of the project is the development of strong collaboration and resource sharing with Australian and Canadian scientists.

Outcomes Report: The Tasman Tidal Dissipation Experiment (TTIDE)

The surface waters of the sea are warmer and less dense that those below and this density difference leads to an enormous amount of isolation between shallow & deep. A bottle tossed in the ocean off Los Angeles might take 5-15 years to drift around the North Pacific and return to its starting point, a distance of 10 thousand kilometers or more. A hypothetical ?drifter? transiting the four kilometers from the top to the bottom of the sea might take one to ten thousand years. This slow pathway is problematic, in that we are rapidly heating our atmosphere and ocean surface and these are isolated from the cooling influence of the waters below. 

The ultimate temperature distribution that the ocean takes on will be a balance between the effects of ocean currents and those of turbulent mixing, which can mix the warmer surface waters with colder water below. The challenge of TTIDE is to understand how mixing processes work deep in the sea.

Deep-ocean mixing requires spatially concentrated sources of energy. One such source is the so-called internal tide, a wave motion that exists in the interior of the sea and can propagate for thousands of kilometers, interact strongly with distant sea floor topography, and trigger localized mixing. Internal tides are created as the surface tidal currents that we are familiar with  flow back and forth over seafloor topography. 

 Computer models predict that the internal tide, once generated at a topographic conversion site, propagates in confined beams across ocean basins and can generate significant mixing upon shoaling. The impact of internal tide shoaling and its associated predictability will be far different if these beams are dispersed by ocean currents, such that the shoaling energy is spread over a wider area and a time-variable range of shoaling topography. 

There are many open questions. Upon shoaling, does the ultimate balance between dissipation and reflection depend primarily on the macro-scale topography of the continental slope? Can ?microscale? topographic features superimposed on the slope significantly affect the overall mixing rates? How well must a geographic region be mapped / resolved before its behavior as a scattering target can be predicted? 

To investigate this sequence of related issues, a group of investigators assembled in 2008-9 to plan the program that became TTIDE, the Tasman Tidal Dissipation Experiment. A tidal beam that is generated at the Macquarie Ridge south of New Zealand and transits the Tasman Sea, shoaling on the east coast of Tasmania, was selected as the subject of the study. The TTIDE-related program TBEAM investigated the propagation of the beam through the energetic and variable currents of the Tasman Sea. TTIDE investigators explored the reflection and dissipation of the beam on the Tasman continental slope. The Australian program T-SHELF quantified the inshore effects of the shoaling process on Tasmania?s energetic continental shelf.

Among the major findings of the TTIDE, the internal tidal beam can indeed survive the currents and eddies in the Tasman Sea. It arrives at the coast of Tasmania and reflects from it largely as expected. Properly analyzed data from satellites that measure the elevation of the sea surface can detect the beam. The distribution of ocean mixing associated with the reflection process depends both on the large (tidal wavelength) scale topography of the continental slope and on the properties of small (tidal excursion distance) scale features which can trigger intense local disturbances. Accurate global models and maps of this process are now feasible, but only if topography is mapped to ~1 km resolution at sites of internal tide generation and shoaling / reflection.
